body.p: To his excellency James F Robinson Governor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky -- your peitioner states that at the last Term of the ^Boyd^ Circuit Court (April 1863) he was fined fifty dollars ($50) for selling Liqour to an infant ^to wit^ Sobble Burgess. he says that Burges was a candidate for the office of Major was as he learned ^since^ under 21 years of age barely had been doing business for some time for himself your petitioner being a Lisensed Tavern Keeper in Boyd County did let said Burgess have some Liquor to treat his friends as he said. that he did not know that he was violating the Law. said Burgess was an inteligent sober man and not doubting his being of age. he prays your exceleny to remit the fine yours & c

I George Burgess of Boyd County states that Soble Burgess is his son that he was well grown & had been doing business for himself that Turman is his neighbour that he had permitted said Son of his to trade with Turman he was candidate as represented by Turman. He states his son is sober ^& was going on 21 years old out of his 20th I think^ He asks that the fine may be remitted against Turman believing in this instance and satisfied that Turman would do his son no injury & violated the Law unintentionally this 4th day of may 1863

we the undersign recommend the case of James L Turman as stated in his petition to be such that the executive should interfere and remit
the fine assessed

J. H. Eastham
James Lampton
George N Brown
Frank Fairbaim
J W Riely
His Excellency the Governor of Kentucky

I was acting Judge of the Boyd Circuit Court, at the time of the rendition of the Judgement against The petitioner Turman and heard the evidence I am satisfied that Turman did not Knowingly violate the Law, he supposed Gobel Burgess was in his majority.

Jas L. Turman
Catlettsburg
Boyd County
Kentucky --

James L Turman
to
Gov of Kentucky

Petitioner for Release fine
Boyd Cir Ct
$50 --
Jas L Turman
Remitted
4th Sept 1863
